Situation1: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Expectation2: Organize and lead religious education classes for children and adults
Situation2: The initial planning meeting for the next season's adult faith formation series is on the calendar.
Story:
I stared at my computer screen, headset pressing into my ear, as another prospect launched into a barrage of technical questions about our new service. The script in front of me felt flimsy, barely covering the basics, and I could sense the caller’s frustration growing. My supervisor expected me to handle every objection smoothly, to keep the conversation moving, but I was floundering, improvising answers and silently praying I wouldn’t say something wrong. 

At the same time, my phone buzzed with a calendar reminder: the planning meeting for the adult faith formation series was about to start. As a priest, I was supposed to guide and inspire, to be fully present for my parishioners, especially when organizing something as important as religious education. I imagined the committee waiting for me, expecting leadership and vision. 

My heart pounded as I weighed the demands—my job needed me to stay on the line, to close the sale, but my calling as a priest demanded my presence and care for my community. I felt torn, caught between two worlds, each expecting my undivided attention, and I didn’t know which voice to answer first.
